event: The first version of Unix operating system is released by Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie at Bell Labs in 1971.
The first computer virus, known as the 'Creeper,' is created in 1971 by Bob Thomas.
On this day in 1983, the Domain Name System (DNS) was introduced, making it easier to navigate the Internet.
In 1981, IBM announced the development of the IBM Personal Computer, paving the way for personal computing.
The first ever computer bug was recorded in 1947 by Grace Hopper, where a moth was found inside a computer.
In 1989, the first website was created by Tim Berners-Lee, leading to the birth of the World Wide Web.
The first personal computer, the Altair 8800, was announced by MITS in 1975.
In 1959, the first computer programming language, Fortran, was officially released to the public.
In 2007, Apple launched the first iPhone, revolutionizing mobile computing.
The Apple Macintosh was announced by Steve Jobs in 1984, featuring a graphical user interface.
In 1999, the first version of the Linux kernel was released by Linus Torvalds.
The first commercial minicomputer, the PDP-1, was released by Digital Equipment Corporation in 1960.
In 1995, Sun Microsystems released the Java programming language, shaping modern web development.
In 1982, the first compact disc player (CDP) was released in Japan, marking the rise of digital audio.
The first computer mouse was patented by Douglas Engelbart in 1970.
In 1994, Netscape Communications released the Netscape Navigator web browser, popularizing Internet browsing.
In 1966, the first high-speed computer memory system was introduced by IBM.
In 1978, the first handheld scientific calculator, the HP-35, was released.
The first Apple II personal computers were sold in 1977.
In 1999, the first commercial version of the wireless protocol Wi-Fi was introduced.
In 1986, the first 'Supercomputer' to be used commercially was unveiled by Cray Research.
In 1993, the Mosaic web browser was released, laying the groundwork for future web browsers.
In 1954, IBM introduced the first computer with an integrated circuit, the IBM 701.
The first portable computer, the Osborne 1, was introduced in 1981.
In 1991, the first version of the Linux kernel was released, with Linus Torvalds at the helm.
The first commercial home video game console, the Magnavox Odyssey, was released in 1972.
In 1996, the first version of the Java programming language for mobile applications was released.
In 1987, the first IBM personal computer with an Intel 80386 processor was introduced.
In 2004, Google launched Gmail, a free email service that revolutionized online communication.
In 1988, the first version of Microsoft Excel for Windows was released.
In 1993, the first version of the Netscape Navigator web browser was released.
In 1992, the first ever text message (SMS) was sent in the UK by Neil Papworth.
In 1956, IBM launched the IBM 305 RAMAC, the first computer with a hard disk drive.
In 1969, ARPANET (the precursor to the Internet) was officially created.
In 1980, the first version of the Apple III was introduced by Apple.
In 1983, the first Apple Lisa computer, which featured a graphical user interface, was introduced.
In 1994, Yahoo! was founded by Jerry Yang and David Filo, becoming one of the first major web directories.
The first ever computer 'bug' was found in 1947, when a moth caused a malfunction in the Harvard Mark II computer.
In 1983, Microsoft released the first version of Word for Windows, paving the way for office productivity software.
The first hand-held calculator, the HP-35, was released by Hewlett-Packard in 1972.
In 1967, the first program to simulate human intelligence (ELIZA) was written by Joseph Weizenbaum.
In 1986, the first Supercomputer to be used commercially was unveiled by Cray Research.
In 2000, the first version of the PHP scripting language was released.
In 1993, the first version of the popular 3D graphics software, AutoCAD, was released by Autodesk.
In 2004, Google launched Gmail, a free email service that revolutionized online communication.
In 1983, the first Microsoft Windows 1.0 was released, marking the beginning of their graphical operating system.
In 1981, the Osborne 1, the first portable computer, was introduced.
In 1996, the first version of the search engine, Yahoo!, was launched by Jerry Yang and David Filo.
In 1959, the first commercial computer programming language, FORTRAN, was officially released.
In 1992, the first successful text message was sent via SMS in the UK by Neil Papworth.
In 1989, Tim Berners-Lee proposed the concept of the World Wide Web at CERN.
In 1993, Mosaic, the first popular web browser, was released, bringing the internet to the masses.
In 1999, the Microsoft Antitrust case began, shaping the future of technology regulation.
In 1995, JavaScript was created by Brendan Eich, making interactive websites possible.
In 1984, Apple introduced the Macintosh, the first personal computer with a graphical user interface (GUI).
In 2005, YouTube was founded by Steve Chen, Chad Hurley, and Jawed Karim.
In 1998, Google began to offer pay-per-click advertising, a model that revolutionized online business.
In 1993, the Intel Pentium processor was introduced, bringing performance to the forefront of personal computers.
In 1994, the first 64-bit RISC processor, the DEC Alpha, was released by Digital Equipment Corporation.
In 1995, Microsoft released Windows 95, one of the most significant versions of Windows.
In 1965, Gordon Moore, co-founder of Intel, made his famous prediction of 'Moore's Law' for the first time.
In 1994, the first version of Netscape Navigator was released, marking the beginning of the browser wars.
In 1969, the first successful transmission over ARPANET (the precursor to the internet) occurred.
In 1997, the IBM Deep Blue computer defeated world chess champion Garry Kasparov.
In 2001, Wikipedia was launched by Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger.
In 1969, the first integrated circuit, the Microchip, was successfully tested by Jack Kilby of Texas Instruments.
In 1983, Microsoft Word for Windows was released as part of their suite of office software.
In 1993, the first version of the popular web browser Netscape Navigator was released.
In 2000, the first ever smartphone (the Nokia 7110) was released with WAP technology for mobile web browsing.
In 1993, the first version of the Intel Pentium processor was released, marking a new era in computing power.
In 2008, Yahoo! announced that it was abandoning its acquisition of Microsoft, which had been on the table for some time.
In 1986, the Cray-2 supercomputer was released, providing massive computational power.
In 1991, the first version of Linux, the open-source operating system, was released by Linus Torvalds.
In 2005, YouTube was founded by three former PayPal employees, Steve Chen, Chad Hurley, and Jawed Karim.
In 1997, the first ever online shopping site, Amazon, was launched by Jeff Bezos.
In 1973, the first commercial email system was introduced, changing communication forever.
In 1995, the first publicly available version of JavaScript was introduced.
In 1986, the first IBM PC-compatible laptop, the Compaq Portable, was introduced.
In 1994, Yahoo! was founded by Jerry Yang and David Filo, becoming one of the first major internet directories.
In 1985, Windows 1.0 was released by Microsoft, offering a graphical user interface for the first time.
In 1993, the first 3D video game, Doom, was released and became a massive success.
In 1987, IBM announced the first personal computer compatible with a Macintosh operating system.
In 2003, Google acquired the Blogger platform, making it a major player in the blogosphere.
In 1999, Linux 2.2 was released, making the open-source operating system even more popular.
In 1991, the first graphical web browser, Mosaic, was launched, sparking the internet revolution.
In 1984, the Apple Macintosh was released to the public, bringing GUI to personal computing.
In 1991, the first ever email marketing campaign was sent by the company Digital Equipment Corporation.
In 2004, Google announced Gmail with 1 GB of storage, leading many to believe it was an April Fools' joke.
In 1987, IBM introduced the PS/2 line of personal computers along with the VGA display standard.
In 2010, Apple released the first iPad, launching the modern tablet computing era.
In 1975, Bill Gates and Paul Allen founded Microsoft in Albuquerque, New Mexico.
In 1992, the Windows 3.1 operating system was released, becoming widely popular in homes and offices.
In 1998, the Mozilla project was announced by Netscape to develop an open-source browser.
In 1969, the RFC 1 document was published, launching the Request for Comments series that underpins the Internet.
In 1976, Apple Computer Company was formed by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne.
In 1983, the Lotus Development Corporation released Lotus 1-2-3, a revolutionary spreadsheet program.
In 1995, the Java programming language was officially introduced by Sun Microsystems.
In 1976, the Apple I computer was released and sold as a fully assembled circuit board.
In 1961, IBM introduced the 1401 Data Processing System, which became one of the most popular computers of the 1960s.
In 1984, Apple released the Apple IIc, a portable version of its popular Apple II computer.
In 1956, MIT researchers demonstrated the first transistorized computer, the TX-0.
In 1985, Intel released the 80386 processor, offering true 32-bit computing.
In 2003, Apple launched the iTunes Music Store, changing the way people bought and listened to music.
In 1973, IBM introduced the Winchester disk drive, a breakthrough in hard drive technology.
In 2002, the Mozilla Foundation was established to support open-source browser development.
In 1982, the Sinclair ZX Spectrum was released, sparking a home computing boom in the UK.
In 1998, Apple introduced the iMac, a colorful all-in-one computer designed by Jony Ive.
In 1989, Nintendo released the Game Boy, launching the era of handheld gaming.
In 1993, the first release of the Mosaic web browser for Windows took place.
In 2005, the first video was uploaded to YouTube by co-founder Jawed Karim.
In 1990, the Hubble Space Telescope was launched, enabled by significant computing advancements.
In 1985, AT&T introduced the Unix System V Release 3, a key step in Unix standardization.
In 1991, the first webcam concept was created at Cambridge University to monitor a coffee pot.
In 1981, Xerox released the Xerox Star, the first commercial system with a GUI.
In 2003, Apple launched the Power Mac G5, the first 64-bit personal computer.
In 1994, CERN officially released the World Wide Web into the public domain.
In 1993, the World Wide Web was made freely available to the public by CERN.
In 1964, Dartmouth College professors John Kemeny and Thomas Kurtz introduced BASIC, a beginner-friendly programming language.
In 1983, Microsoft announced its intention to create a graphical user interface, which would become Windows.
In 1978, the first spam email was sent to 600 people on ARPANET.
In 1984, IBM introduced the PC/AT with the Intel 80286 processor, improving computing speed and multitasking.
In 1988, the Morris Worm led to the formation of CERT, the first response team for internet security threats.
In 1997, IBM's Deep Blue defeated Garry Kasparov in a chess match, a landmark in AI history.
In 1954, the IBM 701 was delivered to Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, one of the first mass-produced computers.
In 1999, the Melissa virus spread through Microsoft Word documents, causing widespread damage.
In 1996, WebTV launched as an internet access product for televisions, later acquired by Microsoft.
In 2001, the Code Red worm exploited vulnerabilities in Microsoft IIS web servers.
In 1997, Google registered its domain name, beginning its journey to dominate the web.
In 2017, the WannaCry ransomware attack began, affecting systems in over 150 countries.
In 2005, Adobe acquired Macromedia, adding Flash and Dreamweaver to its product line.
In 1986, Microsoft released its first version of Excel for Macintosh.
In 1997, Sun Microsystems released Java 1.1, a major step forward in cross-platform computing.
In 1960, the first laser was demonstrated, later used in optical storage and computing.
In 1991, the first version of the Linux kernel was announced by Linus Torvalds on Usenet.
In 1998, the United States Department of Justice and 20 states filed an antitrust case against Microsoft.
In 2006, Twitter was publicly launched, revolutionizing microblogging and online communication.
In 1983, the GNU Project was launched by Richard Stallman to develop a free Unix-like OS.
In 1990, Microsoft released Windows 3.0, a major commercial success.
In 1980, Pac-Man was released by Namco, becoming one of the most iconic games in computing history.
In 2001, Apple opened its first retail stores in Virginia and California.
In 1972, Magnavox released the Odyssey, the first commercial home video game console.
In 1977, Star Wars premiered, inspiring generations of future computer scientists and technologists.
In 1995, Java was officially launched by Sun Microsystems.
In 1999, the soap opera-like legal saga between Microsoft and the US government continued with antitrust rulings.
In 1983, Lotus 1-2-3 debuted, revolutionizing business spreadsheet software.
In 1994, the Bluetooth Special Interest Group was founded, setting the stage for wireless device communication.
In 1987, IBM introduced the PS/2, redefining the PC market with VGA and the 3.5-inch floppy disk.
In 2003, LinkedIn was launched, becoming a leading social network for professionals.
In 1999, Napster was released, transforming how people shared and consumed digital music.
In 1953, the IBM 701, IBM's first commercial scientific computer, was officially introduced.
In 1977, Apple Computer released the Apple II, one of the first successful mass-market PCs.
In 1984, Tetris was created by Alexey Pajitnov at the Soviet Academy of Sciences.
In 2007, Apple announced the release date for the first iPhone, setting the stage for smartphones.
In 1995, PHP was publicly released by Rasmus Lerdorf, enabling dynamic web development.
In 1983, Microsoft introduced Word for DOS, a major step in word processing.
In 1978, Intel released the 8086 processor, which became the basis for the x86 architecture.
In 1993, Adobe Acrobat and the PDF file format were officially launched.
In 2003, the Safari web browser was released for Mac OS X by Apple.
In 1998, Microsoft released Windows 98, a consumer-oriented operating system update.
In 1994, W3C was founded at MIT to lead the development of web standards.
In 1980, Microsoft signed a deal with IBM to provide an operating system, which became MS-DOS.
In 2007, the iPhone entered mass production, transforming the mobile phone industry.
In 1993, Intel released the Pentium processor, marking a leap in PC processing power.
In 1977, Apple shipped its first Apple II units to customers.
In 1997, the Webby Awards were held for the first time, recognizing excellence on the internet.
In 1982, the Commodore 64 was unveiled, becoming one of the best-selling computers of all time.
In 2000, Red Hat Linux 7.0 was released, advancing the adoption of open-source operating systems.
In 1991, Microsoft released MS-DOS 5.0 with a full-screen editor and improved memory management.
In 2004, Firefox 0.9 was released, gaining traction as an alternative to Internet Explorer.
In 1948, the Manchester Small-Scale Experimental Machine ran its first program, the first stored-program computer.
In 1912, Alan Turing was born, whose ideas laid the foundation of modern computing and AI.
In 1987, IBM introduced the PS/2 Model 30, expanding its personal computing line.
In 1998, Microsoft was officially charged with violating antitrust laws by the US Department of Justice.
In 1974, the UPC barcode was scanned for the first time, transforming inventory management and retail.
In 1972, Nolan Bushnell founded Atari, launching the video game industry.
In 1993, Microsoft introduced Windows NT, their first 32-bit operating system for businesses.
In 2007, Apple released the first iPhone, changing the landscape of mobile computing.
In 2005, Apple announced the transition from PowerPC to Intel processors for Mac computers.
In 1979, Sony introduced the Walkman, influencing portable media and digital music design.
In 1994, Amazon was founded by Jeff Bezos as an online bookstore.
In 1980, Steve Ballmer joined Microsoft as its first business manager.
In 1956, MIT's Whirlwind became one of the first real-time computers with graphical output.
In 1996, Dolly the sheep was cloned, using advanced computing for genetic modeling and analysis.
In 1995, the MP3 file format was patented, setting the stage for digital music distribution.
In 2000, Napster was ordered to shut down its service due to copyright infringement.
In 1993, IBM released OS/2 Warp 3, an ambitious but ultimately unsuccessful operating system.
In 1981, Microsoft bought the rights to 86-DOS, the basis for MS-DOS.
In 1962, Telstar, the first active communications satellite, was launched into orbit.
In 2008, Apple launched the App Store, creating a new mobile software economy.
In 1984, IBM released PC-DOS 3.0 to support its new AT computers.
In 2001, Symbian OS was released, powering early smartphones before Android and iOS.
In 2004, Mozilla Firefox 0.9 was released, gaining popularity as a secure web browser.
In 2015, Amazon launched Prime Day, driving massive online sales using advanced cloud infrastructure.
In 1969, Apollo 11 launched with onboard computers far less powerful than modern smartphones.
In 2002, the .us domain was opened to the general public for registration.
In 1968, Intel was founded by Robert Noyce and Gordon Moore.
In 1993, the first version of Adobe PDF Reader was released, standardizing electronic documents.
In 1969, humans landed on the Moon with guidance from computers aboard the Apollo Lunar Module.
In 2005, Google launched Google Earth to the public.
In 2004, Mark Shuttleworth announced Ubuntu, a Linux distro focused on usability and community.
In 1995, the JavaScript programming language was officially introduced by Netscape.
In 1998, the first version of KDE, a desktop environment for Linux, was released.
In 2000, Bluetooth 1.0 specification was finalized, enabling short-range wireless communication.
In 1991, Tim Berners-Lee released files describing his WorldWideWeb project.
In 1993, Windows NT 3.1 was released by Microsoft for high-end workstations and servers.
In 1955, IBM introduced the IBM 608 calculator, the first all-transistor calculator.
In 2015, Microsoft launched Windows 10 as a free upgrade from Windows 7 and 8.
In 1971, the first email program was developed by Ray Tomlinson.
In 2006, the first version of Twitter was publicly released, revolutionizing real-time communication.
In 1981, MTV launched with 'Video Killed the Radio Star,' marking a shift toward digital media consumption.
In 1993, the Mac-based Newton MessagePad was released by Apple, one of the first PDAs.
In 1977, Radio Shack announced the TRS-80, a low-cost personal computer for the home market.
In 2004, Mozilla Firefox 0.9.3 was released, continuing to gain ground against Internet Explorer.
In 2003, Myspace was officially launched, becoming one of the first popular social networking sites.
In 1991, Tim Berners-Lee posted the first web page, launching the World Wide Web publicly.
In 1981, IBM introduced its Personal Computer (IBM 5150), revolutionizing the computing industry.
In 1995, Microsoft released Windows 95 to manufacturers ahead of its public debut later that month.
In 1995, Netscape went public, triggering the dot-com boom and validating the web's economic potential.
In 2000, the first USB flash drive was released in the United States by IBM.
In 2003, the Blaster Worm began spreading through Windows systems, exploiting vulnerabilities in RPC.
In 1981, IBM released the IBM PC, forever changing personal and business computing.
In 2004, Google filed its IPO, raising over 1.6 billion dollars and setting its path to dominance.
In 1998, the iMac G3 went on sale, showcasing Steve Jobs’s renewed vision for Apple.
In 1998, the first public beta of the open-source Mozilla project was released.
In 1993, Microsoft released MS-DOS 6.2 with added disk compression and backup tools.
In 1991, Linus Torvalds announced he was working on a free operating system—Linux was born.
In 1995, Microsoft announced Internet Explorer, entering the web browser market.
In 1991, the Linux kernel version 0.01 was uploaded by Linus Torvalds to an FTP server.
In 1982, the Commodore 64 went on sale, becoming one of the best-selling personal computers.
In 1993, Intel introduced the Pentium processor to replace its aging 486 line.
In 2007, Skype was purchased by eBay for $2.6 billion, aiming to boost its communications platform.
In 2007, the Hashtag (#) was first proposed for use on Twitter by Chris Messina.
In 1995, Microsoft officially released Windows 95 with major media fanfare.
In 1991, Linus Torvalds posted about his new project—Linux—on the MINIX newsgroup.
In 2002, the Mozilla Foundation released Phoenix 0.1, the browser that would become Firefox.
In 2001, the Code Red II worm began circulating, exploiting the same flaw as Code Red.
In 1990, Microsoft released Windows 3.0a with improved multimedia support.
In 2003, Mydoom, one of the fastest spreading email worms, was first detected.
In 1996, Windows NT 4.0 was released, combining the NT kernel with the Windows 95 interface.
In 1994, Adobe released Acrobat Reader free of charge, helping make PDF an internet standard.
In 2008, Google Chrome was announced, introducing a new approach to web browsing.
In 1969, the first Interface Message Processor (IMP) was delivered to UCLA for the ARPANET.
In 1995, eBay was founded by Pierre Omidyar as 'AuctionWeb'.
In 1998, Google was founded by Larry Page and Sergey Brin.
In 1983, IBM introduced the PC XT, its first computer with a hard drive.
In 2006, Hewlett-Packard was implicated in a corporate spying scandal involving private investigators.
In 2005, Apple introduced the iPod nano, replacing the iPod mini.
In 1993, the term 'Eternal September' began as new users flooded Usenet via AOL.
In 1947, the first documented computer bug—a moth—was removed from the Harvard Mark II.
In 2002, Opera 7 beta was released, introducing the Presto layout engine.
In 2001, major networks and data centers were disrupted following the terrorist attacks in the US.
In 1958, Jack Kilby demonstrated the first working integrated circuit at Texas Instruments.
In 1983, Lotus released Symphony, an integrated software suite for DOS.
In 1994, the Netscape browser was renamed from 'Mosaic Netscape' due to trademark issues.
In 1997, Google registered the google.com domain name.
In 1992, IBM introduced ThinkPad laptops, launching a long-running line of business machines.
In 1985, the C programming language was standardized by ANSI.
In 1998, ICANN was formed to manage Internet naming and IP address allocation.
In 1982, emoticons :-) and :-( were first proposed by Scott Fahlman on a Carnegie Mellon bulletin board.
In 2001, Apple released Mac OS X 10.1 Puma, improving system performance and hardware support.
In 1983, Borland released Turbo Pascal, a fast and affordable Pascal compiler for PCs.
In 2003, the BitTorrent protocol was gaining traction for peer-to-peer file sharing.
In 2002, Mozilla Phoenix 0.1 was released, the ancestor of Firefox.
In 1997, Microsoft released Internet Explorer 4.0 as part of its desktop integration strategy.
In 2001, Windows XP was released to manufacturing, combining consumer and business lines.
In 1983, GNU Emacs was released by Richard Stallman, part of the free software movement.
In 1998, Google celebrated its first birthday, retroactively declared their launch date.
In 1987, HyperCard was released for the Macintosh, influencing the development of the web.
In 1996, Palm Pilot surpassed 1 million units sold, becoming a dominant PDA.
In 1997, AOL Instant Messenger (AIM) launched, shaping online chat for a generation.
In 1971, the first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson using ARPANET.
In 1955, ENIAC was officially decommissioned at the University of Pennsylvania.
In 1995, eBay was officially launched by Pierre Omidyar.
In 2011, Siri was introduced as part of the iPhone 4S, bringing voice assistants to mobile.

In 1997, AOL acquired CompuServe, consolidating early internet service providers.
In 2002, Microsoft released Windows XP Media Center Edition, focused on home entertainment.
In 1996, the Internet Archive was founded to preserve the history of the internet.
In 2006, Google announced its acquisition of YouTube for $1.65 billion in stock.
In 1980, the Ethernet standard was published by Xerox, DEC, and Intel.
In 1977, VisiCalc was demonstrated for the first time, the first spreadsheet program for PCs.

In 1983, Lotus was founded by Mitch Kapor, shortly before releasing Lotus 1-2-3.
In 2003, Apple launched iTunes for Windows, expanding its music ecosystem beyond Mac users.
In 1994, Netscape Navigator was released to beta testers.
In 2000, Microsoft released Windows ME, the last OS based on MS-DOS.

In 2003, Apple introduced the iTunes Music Store for Windows.
In 2015, Back to the Future Day was celebrated with real-world tech reflections.
In 2009, Microsoft released Windows 7 to replace the poorly received Windows Vista.
In 2001, Apple introduced the iPod, revolutionizing digital music consumption.
In 2003, the Concorde made its final flight—its control systems had relied on custom computing tech.
In 2001, Microsoft released Windows XP, known for its stability and wide adoption.

In 1998, Mozilla open-sourced its browser code, laying the groundwork for Firefox.
In 1955, Bill Gates was born, later co-founding Microsoft and shaping the software industry.
In 1969, the first message was sent over ARPANET between UCLA and Stanford.

In 2000, the dot-com bubble showed signs of bursting with mass sell-offs in tech stocks.

In 2006, Sony launched the PlayStation 3 in Japan.

In 2006, Nintendo launched the Wii gaming console.

In 1995, Microsoft released Internet Explorer 2.0 with support for JavaScript.

In 1972, the first computerized bulletin board system (CBBS) was conceptualized.

In 2002, the Xbox Live online gaming service launched.
In 1972, Atari released Pong, one of the earliest arcade video games.
In 1975, Bill Gates coined the term 'Micro-Soft' in a letter to Paul Allen.
In 1983, Fred Cohen demonstrated the first self-replicating computer virus as part of his research.

In 1994, Sony released the PlayStation in Japan.
In 2001, McAfee discovered the 'Goner' virus, one of the most destructive email worms of the time.
In 1996, Palm released the PalmPilot Professional, a defining PDA of the era.

In 1999, Napster reached 20 million users, triggering the rise of music piracy concerns.
